data.title: Stoops victim of computer fraud
data.meta_description: The bank account information, birth date and social security number of Oklahoma football coach and former Florida assistant Bob Stoops were stolen and used to create a counterfeit check worth...
data.text:
The bank account information, birth date and social security number of Oklahoma football coach and former Florida assistant Bob Stoops were stolen and used to create a counterfeit check worth $35,000, authorities said.

The thief, who has not been identified, forged Stoops' signature and opened a stock trading account with an online trading service. Stoops was unaware the $35,000 was missing from his account until he received a statement from the online company, Norman Police Lt. Paul Swenson said. His Norman, Okla., bank returned the money to Stoops' account.

MORE COLLEGE FOOTBALL: Virginia Tech's Frank Beamer (Division I-A), Georgia Southern's Paul Johnson (Division I-AA), Northwest Missouri State's Mel Tjeerdsma (AFCA Division II) and Pacific Lutheran's Frosty Westering (AFCA Division III) were named coaches of the year as the American Association finished its annual convention in Anaheim, Calif. . . . Tennessee announced the early signing of top-rated quarterback prospects Casey Clausen and John Rattay. Clausen, of Alemany High in Northridge, Calif., is rated the nation's No. 3 prospect by ESPN's Top 100. Rattay, of Desert Vista High in Phoenix, Ariz., is No. 5 . . . Running back Javis Austin, who lost his right eye in a shooting police say was self-inflicted, is scheduled to return to Clemson for two classes this week. Officials said Austin will keep his scholarship even though he will not be able to play.

COLLEGES: Sickles High senior midfielder Brandon Streicher has orally committed to play soccer for USF, his father said.

TENNIS: Defending champion Todd Martin was ousted from the Sydney International in Australia, losing to Ivan Ljubicic 7-6 (13-11), 6-4. In women's play, eighth-seeded Anna Kournikova beat Jennifer Capriati 6-4, 7-5. Defending titlist Lindsay Davenport beat Elena Likhovtseva 6-1, 6-2. Top-seeded Tommy Haas lost to qualifier Juan Balcells 6-4, 7-5 in the Auckland Open in New Zealand. Fifth-seeded Thomas Johansson lost to Magnus Gustafsson 6-2, 6-3. Qualifier Maria Vento beat third-seeded Patty Schnyder 7-6 (10-8), 6-4 to reach the quarterfinals of the Tasmanian International in Hobart, Australia. Justine Henin ousted seventh-seeded Sylvia Plischke 6-3, 6-1. Pete Sampras beat Richard Krajicek 6-4, 3-6, 7-6 in the Colonial Classic exhibition in Melbourne, Australia. Andre Agassi beat Wayne Ferreira 6-2, 6-4.

AUTO RACING: 1998 Indy 500 winner Eddie Cheever Jr. of the IRL and NASCAR Winston Cup drivers Jeff Gordon, Bobby Labonte and Tony Stewart have been invited to participate in the IROC all-star series.

TELEVISION: CBS expects to complete a deal next week with NBC announcer Dick Enberg.

BOXING: U.S. District Judge John W. Bissell appointed New Jersey lawyer Joseph A. Hayden Jr. as monitor for the scandal-ridden International Federation. It is the first time a U.S. sports organization has come under a stewardship generally reserved for mob-tainted labor unions. Prosecutors asked for a monitor after indicting and suing IBF founder Robert W. Lee Sr. on charges he took bribes to rig rankings . . . Unbeaten IBF junior middleweight champion Fernando Vargas and four others pleaded innocent to felony assault charges in Santa Barbara, Calif., Superior Court. Tennielle Smith, a hairdresser from Philadelphia, will be the opponent for the pro debut of Jacqueline Frazier-Lyde, the daughter of former heavyweight champion Joe Frazier. The match is scheduled for Feb. 6 in Scranton, Pa.

SOCCER: Belgian state police are threatening to strike during the European Championship, a move that would undermine security being prepared for high-profile matches such as the Germany-England game. Monaco beat Troyes 4-1 and leads second-place Lyon by seven points in the French First Division standings. Inter Milan beat city rival AC Milan in the first leg of the Italian Cup quarterfinal. Premiership Leicester beat First Division Fulham 3-0 in a penalty shootout to reach the semifinals of the Worthington Cup.

ICE HOCKEY: Russian Federation president Alexander Steblin was found guilty of violent behavior at Helsinki airport, the Finnish news agency STT reported. Steblin was ordered to pay a fine of $360, as well as $1,200 in damages and doctors fees to a Finnish man with whom he fought at the airport in November, STT said.

MOTORCYCLES: Brandon Grigaliunas, 16, was charged with shooting and killing his father, Scott Grigaliunas, four-time season champion in International Drag Bike Association events, and stepmother Becky, police in Kenton, Ohio, said.

SWIMMING: Lothar Kipke, the former chief doctor of East Germany's team, was convicted of giving steroids to women without telling them. Kipke, 72, was convicted on 58 counts of causing bodily harm. He was fined $3,900 and received a 15-month suspended jail sentence.

BOWLING: Brian LeClair and Jim Long lead after the first round of qualifying in the PBA Tour's National-Senior Doubles event in Reno, Nev. LeClair, of Chatham, N.Y., had a 1,446 six-game pinfall total to lead the National Tour. Long, of Palm City, led the Senior Tour with 1,339 pinfalls.

SPEED SKATING: Jeremy Wotherspoon of Canada set a world record in the 1,000-meter sprint at the Canadian championships in Calgary, in 1 minute, 8.49 seconds.

WINTER SPORTS: Two-time Olympic skier Marcus Nash won the men's 10-kilometer freestyle technique race at the 2002 Olympic trails in Midway, Utah. In the women's 5K classic, Canadian Beckie Scott won her third straight race but, under U.S. rules, the top American is the national champion. Rebecca Dussault was declared the gold medalist although she finished sixth.

_ Compiled from Times wires.
